Cartesian Product
Let $M$ be a set. The Cartesian product of $M$ with itself, denoted as $M \times M$, is the set of all ordered pairs of elements from $M$.
Right Coset
Let $G$ be a group and $H$ a subgroup of $G$. A right coset of $H$ in $G$ is a subset of $G$ of the form $Ha = \{ha; h \in H\}$, where $a \in G$.
Ring Extension
The pair (S, R), where S is a subring of R, is called a ring extension.
Product of Ideals

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
Image of a Ring Homomorphism
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The image of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{im} \varphi$, is defined as $\varphi(R)$, which is a subring of $R'$.
Irreducible Polynomial
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.
Rank of an A-module
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
Algebraic Element

Given a field extension $K \subset L$, an element $\alpha \in L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if it satisfies an algebraic equation over $K$, i.e., an equation $\alpha^{n}+c_{1} \alpha^{n-1}+\ldots+c_{n}=0$ with coefficients $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{n} \in K$.
Splitting field of Family of Polynomials

A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).
Splitting Field of Polynomial
A splitting field $L$ of a polynomial $f \\(in K[X]\\) with coefficients in a field $K$ is a field extension $L / K$ where the polynomial $f$ splits into linear factors.
Symmetric Group
The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
Domain
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A right coset is defined in terms of a group and a subgroup. Therefore, the concept of a group must be defined before defining a right coset.
A ring extension is defined as a pair where one is a subring of the other. Therefore, the concept of a subring must be defined before defining a ring extension.
The product of ideals is defined in terms of ideals in a ring. Therefore, the concept of an ideal must be defined before defining the product of ideals.
The image of a ring homomorphism is defined in terms of a ring homomorphism. Therefore, the concept of a ring homomorphism must be defined before defining the image of a ring homomorphism.
An irreducible polynomial is defined in terms of a polynomial in a ring. Therefore, the concept of a polynomial and a ring must be defined before defining an irreducible polynomial.
The rank of an A-module is defined in terms of a module. Therefore, the concept of a module must be defined before defining the rank of an A-module.
An algebraic element is defined in terms of a field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined before defining an algebraic element.

A splitting field of a family of polynomials is defined in terms of a field extension and polynomials. Therefore, the concepts of a field extension and polynomials must be defined before defining a splitting field of a family of polynomials.

A splitting field of a polynomial is defined in terms of a field extension and a polynomial. Therefore, the concepts of a field extension and a polynomial must be defined before defining a splitting field of a polynomial.
The symmetric group is defined in terms of bijective self-maps. Therefore, the concept of a bijective self-map must be defined before defining the symmetric group.
The domain of a function is defined in terms of a function. Therefore, the concept of a function must be defined before defining the domain of a function.
